p: Within its family, influenza interacts between types (A and B), subtypes (e.g., H3N2, H1N1), and strains. Competitive exclusion due to homologous immunity is widely accepted [ 56, 57] and has been applied extensively in models of influenza strain coexistence [ 58, 59]. Antigenic change (measured through antigenic distance) occurs constantly in influenza, strongly indicating that the virus escapes from immunity resulting from prior infection by genetic change [ 60]. Interestingly, there is mounting evidence that the first influenza infection is important and may affect severity of future infections [ 61â€“ 63]. Some evidence also supports the finding that influenza can interact with other influenza viruses and noninfluenza respiratory viruses via nonspecific immunity following infection [ 64, 65].
